                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">Translation Theory and Practice (MA)</h1>
<p class="p"> The Translation Theory and Practice MA is taught by staff from a wide 
range of departments at UCL. Students benefit from a flexible programme 
of study that allows for various pathways and can include practical 
translation work involving particular language combinations, modules on 
electronic communication and translation technology, and more 
theoretical translation studies. The dissertation either consists of a translation from or into English,
or of a study of existing translations.</p>
<p class="p">Located in the heart of multicultural London, UCL provides a uniquely rich environment for studying and researching translation in all its facets, taught by specialist translation staff with a divers range of research interests including translation and the web, theatre translation, and Chinese translation.</p>
<p class="p">The MA is truly interdisciplinary, with access to experts in an unrivalled variety of languages and disciplines from across Europe and further afield. This allows students to customise their own programmes in relation to their language competencies and other academic and professional interests.</p>
<p class="p">UCL translation students are highly valued by the translation industry, with workshops and networking events organised during the year.</p>
<!-- Subtemplate: 2 columns with 50/50 division -->  
<section class="middle-split"> 

  <section class="middle-split__column1"> 
    

<h2 class="heading"><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/centras/study/postgraduate-taught/translation-theory-and-practice/modules" target="_self">Modules</a></h2>





<p class="p"> View core and optional module information for this pathway. <br /></p>


  </section> 
 
  <section class="middle-split__column2"> 
    

<h2 class="heading"><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/centras/study/postgraduate-taught/translation-theory-and-practice/apply" target="_self">Apply</a></h2>





<p class="p"> View entry requirements and find out how to apply. <br /></p>

 
      <!-- right content block --> 
  </section> 
</section>


<div class="prebox">
<section class="box box--bar-thin">
  
   
  <h1 class="heading">Careers</h1>
<p class="p"> There is an ever-growing demand for highly-trained commercial, literary and other types of translators in the private as well as in the public sector and in international organisations, in Britain and abroad. Other career paths include the media, publishing and education.</p>
<p class="clearfix">
 <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/centras/study/postgraduate-taught/translation-theory-and-practice/careers"
    class="cta btn pull-right"
    onclick="_gaq.push(['_trackEvent','CTA','Click','careers'])">

   Find out more

 </a>
</p>


</section>

</div>

<section class="box box--bar-thin">
  
  <i class="fa fa-key"></i> 
  

<h3 class="heading">Key Information</h3>








<h5 class="heading">Programme Start Date</h5>



<p class="p">September 2016<br /></p>



<h5 class="heading">Mode of Study</h5>



<p class="p">Full-time: 1 year<br />Part-time: 2 years<br /></p>



<h5 class="heading">Tuition Fees</h5>



<p class="p"> <strong>UK/EU:</strong><br />Full-time: £9,020<br />Part-time: £4,510<br /><br /><strong>Overseas:</strong><br />Full-time: £18,670<br />Part-time: £9,285<br /><br /></p>


</section>

</div>

                        <h3>No information is currently available for this degree. If this degree programme is visible in the list of degrees available on the graduate website, could you please report this page to <a href="mailto:pg-updates@ucl.ac.uk">pg-updates@ucl.ac.uk</a> as soon as possible.</h3>

<div class="prebox">
<section class="box box--bar-thin">
  
  <i class="fa fa-key"></i> 
  

<h3 class="heading">Key Information</h3>








<h5 class="heading">Programme Start Date</h5>



<p class="p">September 2016<br /></p>



<h5 class="heading">Mode of Study</h5>



<p class="p">Full-time: 1 year<br />Part-time: 2 years<br /></p>



<h5 class="heading">Tuition Fees</h5>



<p class="p"> <strong>UK/EU:</strong><br />Full-time: £9,020<br />Part-time: £4,510<br /><br /><strong>Overseas:</strong><br />Full-time: £18,670<br />Part-time: £9,285<br /><br /></p>


</section>

</div>


<div class="prebox">
<section class="box box--bar-thin">
  
  <i class="fa fa-envelope-o"></i> 
  

<h3 class="heading">Contact Details</h3>








<h5 class="heading">Programme Administrator:</h5>



<p class="p">Ms Amy Connolly<br /><a href="mailto:a.connolly@ucl.ac.uk" target="_self">a.connolly@ucl.ac.uk<br /></a>+44 (0)20 7679 9323</p>



<h5 class="heading">Admissions Officer:</h5>



<p class="p">Ms Jo Wolff<br /><a href="mailto:selcs.admissions@ucl.ac.uk" target="_self">selcs.admissions@ucl.ac.uk</a><br />+44 (0)20 7679 3096<br /> </p>


</section>

(function(){
  if (window.BOOMR && window.BOOMR.version) { return; }
  var dom,doc,where,iframe = document.createElement("iframe"),win = window;

  function boomerangSaveLoadTime(e) {
    win.BOOMR_onload=(e && e.timeStamp) || new Date().getTime();
  }
  if (win.addEventListener) {
    win.addEventListener("load", boomerangSaveLoadTime, false);
  } else if (win.attachEvent) {
    win.attachEvent("onload", boomerangSaveLoadTime);
  }

  iframe.src = "javascript:void(0)";
  iframe.title = ""; iframe.role = "presentation";
  (iframe.frameElement || iframe).style.cssText = "width:0;height:0;border:0;display:none;";
  where = document.getElementsByTagName("script")[0];
  where.parentNode.insertBefore(iframe, where);

  try {
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  } catch(e) {
    dom = document.domain;
    iframe.src="javascript:var d=document.open();d.domain='"+dom+"';void(0);";
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  }
  doc.open()._l = function() {
    var js = this.createElement("script");
    if (dom) { this.domain = dom; }
    js.id = "boomr-if-as";
    js.src = "//c.go-mpulse.net/boomerang/" +
    "SUWW2-HAKPB-Q4WN7-TQ6VL-GTMT2";
    BOOMR_lstart=new Date().getTime();
    this.body.appendChild(js);
  };
  doc.write('<body onload="document._l();">');
  doc.close();
})();
</script>

                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">Translation Theory and Practice MA</h1>
<p class="p"> The MA programme requires a total of 180 credits. The
 core modules are compulsory and constitute of the required 90 credits. The other 90 credits can be chosen from the list of modules below, subject to availability and departmental approval.There may be certain language or other 
prerequisites for optional modules. Please note that some modules fill up very quickly, whilst others are sometimes withdrawn according to student demand, so places cannot be guaranteed.</p>
<hr class="rule" />


<h3 class="heading">Core Modules</h3>




<ul class="disc">
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/centras/study/postgraduate-taught/ma-modules/TRTPG001" target="_self">TRTPG001 – Translation Studies </a>

 (30 credits)</li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/centras/study/postgraduate-taught/ma-modules/TRTPG099" target="_self">TRTPG099 – Dissertation </a>(60 credits)</li>
</ul>
<hr class="rule" />
<!-- Subtemplate: 2 columns with 50/50 division -->  
<section class="middle-split"> 

  <section class="middle-split__column1"> 
    


<h3 class="heading">Suggested Modules</h3>




<ul class="disc">
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/centras/study/postgraduate-taught/ma-modules/TRTPG002" target="_self">TRTPG002 – The Interaction and Language Management
of Interpreting</a> (15 credits)</li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/centras/study/postgraduate-taught/ma-modules/TRTPG003" target="_self">TRTPG003 – The Historical and Social Context of
Interpreting </a>(15 credits)</li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/centras/study/postgraduate-taught/ma-modules/TRTPG004" target="_self">TRTPG004 – Understanding and Using
Translation Technology I </a>(15 credits) </li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/centras/study/postgraduate-taught/ma-modules/TRTPG005" target="_self">TRTPG005 – Understanding and Using
Translation Technology II </a>(15 credits) Please note: you can only take this module if you have previously taken TRTPG004</li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/centras/study/postgraduate-taught/ma-modules/TRTPG007" target="_self">TRTPG007 – Advanced Translation into Chinese</a> (30 credits) </li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/centras/study/postgraduate-taught/ma-modules/TRTPG008" target="_self">TRTPG008 – Translation and the Web</a> (15 credits) **Not running 2016-17**</li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/centras/study/postgraduate-taught/ma-modules/TRTPG009-10" target="_self">TRTPG009 - Translation in History: Theory, Practice and Reception (20 credits)</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/centras/study/postgraduate-taught/ma-modules/TRTPG009-10" target="_self">TRTPG010 - Translation in History: Theory, Practice and Reception (15 credits)</a></li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/selcs/prospective-students/postgraduate/ma-modules/dutcg502-advanced-translation-dutch-into-english" target="_self">DUTCG502  – Advanced Translation from Dutch into
English</a> (30 credits)</li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/selcs/prospective-students/postgraduate/ma-modules/frengt01-advanced-translation" target="_self">FRENGT01 – Advanced Translation from French to
English</a> (30 credits)</li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/selcs/prospective-students/postgraduate/ma-modules/frengt03" target="_self">FRENGT03 - Translation into French (Advanced)</a> (30 credits)</li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/selcs/prospective-students/postgraduate/ma-modules/ma-modules-14-15/germ4001-translation-from-and-into-german" target="_self">GERMG032  – Translation from and into German</a>

(30 credits)</li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/hebrew-jewish/prospective-students/postgraduate" target="_self">HEBRG036 – Advanced Modern Hebrew, non-fiction</a> (30 credits)<strong> </strong>Please note: this course has language prerequisites. <strong><br /></strong></li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/chinahealth/teaching/reading_translation_1" target="_self">HISTGC03 – (Chinese) Translation and Direct
Reading I</a> (30 credits)</li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/selcs/prospective-students/postgraduate/ma-modules/italg019-advanced-translation-from-and-into-italian" target="_self">ITALG019 – Advanced Translation from Italian into
English </a>(30 credits)</li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/lifesciences-faculty-php/courses/viewcourse.php?coursecode=PLING151" target="_self">PLING151 – Linguistics of Sign Languages</a> (15 credits)
</li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/lifesciences-faculty-php/courses/search.php?action=single&amp;coursecode=PLING150" target="_self">PLING150 – Sociolinguistics</a> (15 credits)</li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/selcs/prospective-students/postgraduate/ma-modules/scang001-advanced-scandinavian-translation-scandinavian-into-english" target="_self">SCANG001  – Advanced Translation from a
Scandinavian Language into English</a> (30 credits)</li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/ssees/masters-courses-2014-15/current-course-outlines/lc_seesge94" target="_self">SEESGE94 –  Linguistic Methods</a> (30 credits)</li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/ssees/masters-courses-2014-15/current-course-outlines/lang_seesgr31" target="_self">SEESGR31 – Advanced Russian</a> (30 credits)</li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/ssees/masters-courses-2014-15/current-course-outlines/lang_seesgr32" target="_self">SEESGR32 – Advanced Superior: Russian </a>(30 credits)</li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/ssees/masters-courses-2014-15/current-course-outlines/lang-seesgr16" target="_self">SEESGR16 – Intermediate Plus: Russian (30 credits)</a></li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/selcs/prospective-students/postgraduate/ma-modules/spang019-advanced-translation-from-and-into-spanish" target="_self">SPANG019 – Advanced Translation from and into
Spanish</a> (30 credits)</li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/centras/study/postgraduate-taught/msc-modules/trang013" target="_self">TRANG013 - Accessibility to the Media</a> (15 credits)</li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/centras/study/postgraduate-taught/msc-modules/trang015" target="_self">TRANG015 - Localisation</a> (15 credits)</li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/centras/study/postgraduate-taught/msc-modules/trang017" target="_self">TRANG017 - Professional Skills for Translators</a> (15 credits)</li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/centras/study/postgraduate-taught/msc-modules/trang020" target="_self">TRANG020 - Scientific and Technical Translation</a> (15 credits)</li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/centras/study/postgraduate-taught/msc-modules/trang021" target="_self">TRANG021 - Medical Translation</a> (15 credits)</li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/centras/study/postgraduate-taught/msc-modules/trang024" target="_self">TRANG024 - Subtitling</a> (15 credits)</li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/centras/study/postgraduate-taught/msc-modules/trang025" target="_self">TRANG025 - Translating for Voiceover &amp; Dubbing</a> (15 credits)</li>
</ul>
<p class="p">If you wish to take any of any of the modules above beginning <strong>HEBRG*, HISTG*, PLING*, SEESG*</strong>), please contact the relevant departmental administrator in the 
first instance. <br /></p>


  </section> 
 
  <section class="middle-split__column2"> 
    


<h3 class="heading">Optional Modules</h3>




<ul class="disc">
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/comparative-literature/postgraduate/comparative-literature-ma/modules/clitg001-modern-literary-theory" target="_self">LITCG001 – Modern Literary Theory</a> (30 credits) </li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/comparative-literature/postgraduate/comparative-literature-ma/modules/clitg003-comparative-literary-studies" target="_self">LITCG003 – Comparative Literary Studies</a>

(30 credits)</li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/dis/study/pg/INSTG017" target="_self">INSTG017 – Internet Technologies

</a>(15 credits)</li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/dis/study/pg/INSTG027" target="_self">INSTG027 – Principles of Computing and Information Technology</a> (15 credits)</li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/dis/study/pg/INSTG038" target="_self">INSTG038 – Electronic Publishing

</a>(15 credits)</li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/dis/study/pg/INSTG035" target="_self">INSTG035 – Systems Management
</a>
(15 credits)</li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/dis/study/pg/INSTG018" target="_self">INSTG018 – Introduction to Programming and Database Querying
</a>(15 credits)</li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/dis/study/pg/INSTG019" target="_self">INSTG019 – Legal and Social Aspects of Electronic Publishing</a>

(15 credits)</li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/dis/study/pg/INSTG008" target="_self">INSTG008 – Digital Resources in
the Humanities</a> (15 credits)</li>
</ul>


<h3 class="heading">Check the following programmes for additional modules:</h3>




<ul class="disc">
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/comparative-literature/postgraduate/comparative-literature-ma/structure" target="_self">Comparative
Literature</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/european-studies/prospective-students" target="_self">European Studies</a></li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/european-culture-and-thought/prospective-students" target="_self">European Thought and
Culture</a></li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/gender-studies/prospective-students/gender-society-and-representation-ma" target="_self">Gender, Society and
Representation</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/filmstudies/prospective-students/film-studies-ma" target="_self">Film Studies</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/ssees/prospective-students/graduate-taught" target="_self">SSEES MA programmes</a> </li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/clie/" target="_self">Centre for Languages
and International Education (CLIE)</a> Please note: any CLIE module you select must
have a <strong>postgraduate module code</strong>. </li>
</ul>
<p class="p"> If you are interested in taking modules from the Department of Information 
Studies (codes beginning <strong>INSTG</strong>), please contact <a href="mailto:k.michaels@ucl.ac.uk" target="_self">Kerstin Michaels</a> in the first instance.</p>

 
      <!-- right content block --> 
  </section> 
</section>

                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">Postgraduate (Research)</h1>
<p class="p">Research students undertake original research leading to the submission of a thesis. They work under the supervision of a Principal and a Secondary Supervisor. They do not normally attend taught courses but follow a tailor-made programme of skills training and personal development courses. To be admitted as a research student you need a Master’s degree with a good grade in a relevant subject. All research students at UCL initially register as MPhil students and, provided they have made satisfactory progress, can upgrade to PhD status after a year (or two years for part-time students). Full-time PhD study normally takes a minimum of three years, part-time study a minimum of five years. </p>

<h2 class="heading">Prospective PhD Applicants</h2>





<p class="p">CenTraS invites applications from suitably qualified students wishing to undertake research on any aspect of translation.</p>
<p class="p">If you wish to apply for admission to UCL as a research student in translation studies, you should, in the first instance, and before you complete the UCL online application form, contact the CenTraS Director, <a href="mailto:t.hermans@ucl.ac.uk" target="_self">Professor Theo Hermans</a>, with (a) details of your educational background, (b) an outline research project proposal, and (c) an indication of how you propose to fund your study.</p>
<p class="p">Information on the application process, general entry requirements, tuition fees, accommodation and the UCL Doctoral School can be found on the <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/centras/study/postgraduate-research/www.grad.ucl.ac.uk" target="_self">Doctoral School website</a>. </p>
<p class="p">Unlike taught programmes, which start in September, a research degree can be started at any time of the year.</p>


<h3 class="heading">Research Facilities</h3>




<p class="p">UCL research students have access to a wealth of library and other resources. UCL’s own libraries cover all subjects and almost all European languages. Beyond UCL, and within easy walking distance, there are the libraries of the University of London, the School of Oriental and African Studies (SOAS), the London School of Economics and Political Science (LSE) and the British Library.</p>
<p class="p">CenTraS research students can make use of a dedicated cluster room (the TransCluster) housing 60 computers with specialist software. They share a common room with other research students. </p>


<h3 class="heading">Being a CenTraS research student</h3>




<p class="p">As a research student in CenTraS you work, under supervision, on your own project. You follow a personal programme of skills training, which is documented in an online logbook. You engage with your peers in regular research seminars and other events, and you attend public lectures. Research students in their second year and beyond may do a certain amount of teaching on the MA in Translation and the MSc in Specialised Translation.</p>
<p class="p">CenTraS currently has around 30 PhD students and several <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/international/affiliate/visiting-research-students" target="_self">Visiting Research Students</a>.</p>
<p class="p">• <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/centras/study/postgraduate-research/current-phd">Current PhD Students</a></p>


<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

    win.BOOMR_onload=(e && e.timeStamp) || new Date().getTime();
  }
  if (win.addEventListener) {
    win.addEventListener("load", boomerangSaveLoadTime, false);

  doc.close();
})();

                                  <div class="info">
                                    <h2 class="heading">The resource cannot be found</h2>
                                    <p class="p">
                                      <acronym title="Uniform Resource Locator">URL</acronym>:
                                      https://www.ucl.ac.uk/centras/study/postgraduate-research/www.grad.ucl.ac.uk
                                      <br /><br />
                                    </p>
                                    <h4 class="heading">
                                      Most likely causes:
                                    </h4>
                                      <ul>
                                          <li>There might be a typing error in the address.</li>
                                          <li>If you clicked on a link, it may be out of date.</li>
                                      </ul>
                                    <h4 class="heading">
                                      What you can try:
                                    </h4>
                                      <ul>
                                          <li>Retype the address.</li>
                                          <li>Use the search box above to find what you're looking for.</li>
                                          <li>Go to <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk" title="UCL Website">www.ucl.ac.uk</a> and look for the information you want.</li>
                                          <li><a href="javascript:history.back()" title="Back to previous page">Go back to the previous page.</a></li>
                                      </ul>
                                    <h4 class="heading">
                                      More information:
                                    </h4>
                                    <p class="p">
                                        This error (<acronym title="Hypertext Transfer Protocol">HTTP</acronym> 404 Not Found) means that you have connected to the UCL Website, but the page you wanted was not found. It's possible that the webpage is temporarily unavailable. Alternatively, the UCL Website might have changed or removed the webpage. 
                                    </p>
                                  </div>

(function(){
  if (window.BOOMR && window.BOOMR.version) { return; }
  var dom,doc,where,iframe = document.createElement("iframe"),win = window;

  function boomerangSaveLoadTime(e) {
    win.BOOMR_onload=(e && e.timeStamp) || new Date().getTime();
  }
  if (win.addEventListener) {
    win.addEventListener("load", boomerangSaveLoadTime, false);
  } else if (win.attachEvent) {
    win.attachEvent("onload", boomerangSaveLoadTime);
  }

  iframe.src = "javascript:void(0)";
  iframe.title = ""; iframe.role = "presentation";
  (iframe.frameElement || iframe).style.cssText = "width:0;height:0;border:0;display:none;";
  where = document.getElementsByTagName("script")[0];
  where.parentNode.insertBefore(iframe, where);

  try {
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  } catch(e) {
    dom = document.domain;
    iframe.src="javascript:var d=document.open();d.domain='"+dom+"';void(0);";
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  }
  doc.open()._l = function() {
    var js = this.createElement("script");
    if (dom) { this.domain = dom; }
    js.id = "boomr-if-as";
    js.src = "//c.go-mpulse.net/boomerang/" +
    "SUWW2-HAKPB-Q4WN7-TQ6VL-GTMT2";
    BOOMR_lstart=new Date().getTime();
    this.body.appendChild(js);
  };
  doc.write('<body onload="document._l();">');
  doc.close();
})();
</script>

<h1 class="heading">Postgraduate Taught</h1>
<!-- Subtemplate: 2 columns with 50/50 division -->  
<section class="middle-split"> 

  <section class="middle-split__column1"> 
    

<div class="prebox">
<section class="box box--bar-thick">
  
   
  

<h2 class="heading">MSc</h2>





<p class="p"><em>2018-19 pathways:</em><br /></p>
<ul class="disc">
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/centras/study/postgraduate-taught/specialised-translation-audiovisual-msc" target="_self">Specialised Translation (Audiovisual) MSc



</a></li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/centras/study/postgraduate-taught/specialised-translation-scientific-technical-medical-msc">Specialised
Translation (Scientific, Technical and Medical) MSc</a></li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/centras/study/postgraduate-taught/specialised-translation-interpreting-msc" target="_self">Specialised
Translation with Interpreting MSc</a></li>
</ul>


</section>

</div>



  </section> 
 
  <section class="middle-split__column2"> 
    

<div class="prebox">
<section class="box box--bar-thick">
  
   
  

<h2 class="heading">MA</h2>





<p class="p"><em>2018-19 pathways:</em></p>
<ul class="disc">
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/centras/study/postgraduate-taught/translation-studies-ma">Translation MA (Translation Studies)</a></li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/centras/study/postgraduate-taught/translation-culture-ma">Translation MA (Translation and Culture) </a></li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/centras/study/postgraduate-taught/translation-research-ma">Translation MA (Research)</a></li>
</ul>


</section>

</div>


 
      <!-- right content block --> 
  </section>

(function(){
  if (window.BOOMR && window.BOOMR.version) { return; }
  var dom,doc,where,iframe = document.createElement("iframe"),win = window;

  function boomerangSaveLoadTime(e) {
    win.BOOMR_onload=(e && e.timeStamp) || new Date().getTime();
  }
  if (win.addEventListener) {
    win.addEventListener("load", boomerangSaveLoadTime, false);
  } else if (win.attachEvent) {
    win.attachEvent("onload", boomerangSaveLoadTime);
  }

  iframe.src = "javascript:void(0)";
  iframe.title = ""; iframe.role = "presentation";
  (iframe.frameElement || iframe).style.cssText = "width:0;height:0;border:0;display:none;";
  where = document.getElementsByTagName("script")[0];
  where.parentNode.insertBefore(iframe, where);

  try {
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  } catch(e) {
    dom = document.domain;
    iframe.src="javascript:var d=document.open();d.domain='"+dom+"';void(0);";
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  }
  doc.open()._l = function() {
    var js = this.createElement("script");
    if (dom) { this.domain = dom; }
    js.id = "boomr-if-as";
    js.src = "//c.go-mpulse.net/boomerang/" +
    "SUWW2-HAKPB-Q4WN7-TQ6VL-GTMT2";
    BOOMR_lstart=new Date().getTime();
    this.body.appendChild(js);
  };
  doc.write('<body onload="document._l();">');
  doc.close();
})();
</script>


        <link id="respond-proxy" rel="respond-proxy"
              href="//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/indigo/js/respond-x-domain/respond-proxy.html" />
        <link href="/globals/respond.proxy.gif" id="respond-redirect" rel="respond-redirect" />

</head>

                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">TRTPG001 - Translation Studies</h1>
<p class="p">The principal aim of this module is to give an understanding of the nature of translation and its significance as a cultural and historical force. The module is made up of three strands, comprised of translation theory, history and case studies. Classes on theoretical aspects consider different ways of conceptualizing and studying translation. The historical part investigates changing views of translation in the Western tradition over centuries, from St Jerome to Jacques Derrida. A series of case studies highlights particular topics and issues in the practice of translation; topics in previous years have included audio visual translation for opera and translating Somali poetry. By the end of the module you will have acquired a grasp of key concepts related to translation and its history, an appreciation of translation as a cultural phenomenon, and an ability to analyse translations from different viewpoints and investigate the associated theoretical and ethical issues.</p>
<p class="p">Credits: 30</p>
<p class="p">Assessment: Two 1,500 word essays and one 3,000 word essay</p>
<p class="p">Module convenor: Dr Geraldine Brodie</p>


<h3 class="heading"></h3>





<h2 class="heading">Preparatory Reading and Set Texts</h2>








<h4 class="heading">Set text</h4>



<p class="p">Lawrence Venuti, ed., The Translation Studies Reader, London &amp; New York: Routledge, 2000, 3rd ed. 2012.</p>



<h4 class="heading">Preparatory reading</h4>



<p class="p">Karin Littau and Piotr Kuhiwczak, eds., A Companion to Translation Studies, Clevedon: Multilingual Matters, 2007.</p>
<p class="p">Jeremy Munday, Introducing Translation Studies. Theories and Applications, London &amp; New York: Routledge, 2001, 3rd ed. 2012.</p>
<p class="p">Anthony Pym, Exploring Translation Theories, London &amp; New York: Routledge, 2010.</p>


<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">TRTPG002 - The Interaction and Language Management of Interpreting</h1>
<p class="p"> This module consists of a series of lectures examining: roles of interpreters in interaction; interaction management in interpreter and remote-interpreter mediated events; the language product of interpreters; the prosody of interpreting; the pragmatic decisions made by interpreters; register in interpreting; interpreting and cognition; interpreting, fatigue and team working; interpreters and language directionality. </p>
<p class="p">Credits: 15</p>
<p class="p">Assessment: Students are assessed by course work (100%). The course work consists of either a 1,500 word essay analysing a 5-minute interpretation with an ELAN annotation, or a 3,000 word essay from a list of questions.</p>
<p class="p">Tutor: TBC</p>


<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

                    <div class="content-footer">
                                        <hr />
                <div id="content-footer"></div>

                <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/centras/study/postgraduate-taught/ma-modules/TRTPG003">TRTPG003 - The Historical and Social Context of...</a>

                    <!--endnoindex-->
                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">TRTPG003 - The Historical and Social Context of Interpreting</h1>
<p class="p">This module consists of a series of lectures examining: the historical development of interpreting; the influence of technology on interpreting provision; routes to professionalization of interpreters; conference interpreting provision, language status and institutions; community interpreting, interpreting as interaction and interpreting as a social practice; legislation, human rights and language politics; interpreting in the media, voice, in-vision and audio description. It aims to develop students' understanding of the different tensions and mechanism at play when interpreting is provided. </p>
<p class="p">Credits: 15</p>
<p class="p">Assessment: One 3,000 word essay</p>
<p class="p">Tutor: TBC</p>


<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

                    <div class="content-footer">
                                        <hr />
                <div id="content-footer"></div>

                    </div>

                    </div>
                     <div class="content-sidebar">
                                        <div class="site-content__sidebar">

<section class="box box--None">
  
  <i class="fa None"></i> 
  <h2 class="heading">UCL International Student Support</h2>
<ul class="disc">
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/iss" target="_self">Important information for international students</a></li>
</ul>


</section>

</div>


<div class="prebox">
<section class="box box--None">
  
  <i class="fa None"></i> 
  <h2 class="heading">Funding</h2>
<ul class="disc">

<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/scholarships/scholarships/graduate/" target="_self">Graduate Scholarships &amp; Awards</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.grad.ucl.ac.uk/funds/" target="_self">UCL Doctoral School Funding</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/ah/figs/wolfson-postgraduate-scholarship" target="_self">Wolfson Scholarships</a></li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/ah/scholarships-and-funding/leverhulme-trust-early-career-fellowships" target="_self">Leverhulme Trust Early Careers Fellowships</a></li>
</ul>


<h4 class="heading"></h4>






</section>

            <ul class="footer__list list-unstyled">
                <li class="footer__item"><a href="//www.ucl.ac.uk/departments/faculties">Faculties and departments</a></li>

        <article class="block block--col-2">
            <h2 class="as-h5">UCL locations</h2>
            <ul class="footer__list list-unstyled">

                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">TRTPG004 - Understanding and Using Translation Technology I</h1>
<p class="p"> The module covers the use of different computer-based methodologies to improve translation output, in terms of both speed and accuracy. It aims to introduce you to the following activities and/or technologies, all of which are employed in the translation industry: terminology mining on the WWW, terminology management, machine translation and translation memory (covering the use of two different systems). Although it has an element of theory the module is largely practical in nature. The module will be taught via a weekly two-hour session in a computer cluster. Understanding and using Translation Technology II is a continuation of this module.</p>
<p class="p">Credits: 15</p>
<p class="p">Assessment: Report on project (2,500 words plus translation and supporting files)</p>
<p class="p">Tutor: Dr Mark Shuttleworth</p>

<h2 class="heading">Preparatory Reading</h2>





<p class="p">EITHER:</p>
<p class="p">Austermühl, Frank (2001) Electronic Tools for Translators, Manchester: St. Jerome Publishing.</p>
<p class="p">OR:</p>
<p class="p">Bowker, L. (2002) Computer-aided Translation Technology: A Practical Introduction, Ottawa: University of Ottawa Press.</p>


<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

                    <div class="content-footer">
                                        <hr />
                <div id="content-footer"></div>

                    </div>

                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">TRTPG005 - Understanding and Using Translation Technology II</h1>
<p class="p"> This module is a continuation of Translation Technology I. First of all, we will be covering a third translation memory system and considering the question of evaluating TM systems. Following that, the module moves on to look at techniques of terminology extraction, methodologies for localising software and web content, and a discussion of how to customise machine translation engines. Taken together, the two modules provide participants with a good overview of most types of translation technology. The module will be taught via a weekly two-hour session in a computer cluster. Most of these sessions will be practical in nature but there will be a small number of lecture-style presentations as well.</p>
<p class="p">Credits: 15</p>
<p class="p">Assessment: One 3,000 word essay</p>
<p class="p">Module convenor: Dr Mark Shuttleworth</p>
<p class="p">Prerequisite: TRTPG004 – Understanding and using Translation Technology I</p>
<p class="p"><strong>In collaboration with:</strong></p>
<a class="image" href="http://kantanmt.com/" title="Kantan Logo" target="_self"><img src="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/centras/images/images-in-indigo/kantan-logo" width="250" height="61" alt="Kantan Logo" class="medium-image" title="Kantan Logo" /></a>

<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

                    <div class="content-footer">
                                        <hr />
                <div id="content-footer"></div>

                    </div>

                    </div>

        <script>
            var cuttingTheMustard = document.querySelector && window.localStorage && window.addEventListener;

            Modernizr.load({
                //cutting the mustard as used by the BBC
                test : cuttingTheMustard
                //if old browser load the shiv
                ,nope : [
                    '//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/indigo/js/lib/html5shiv-printshiv.min.js'
                    ,'//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/indigo/js/lib/respond.min.js'
                    ,'//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/indigo/js/lib/respond.proxy.min.js'
                ]
            });
            //set conditional assets for main.js
            var globalSiteSpecificVars = {
                pathToJquery: '//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/indigo/js/lib/jquery-1.9.1.min'
                ,googleAnalyticsIdsArray: ['google205af8501c1abd6c.html']//specify array of site specific id's NOT UCL generic UA-943297-1
            }
            if(cuttingTheMustard){
                globalSiteSpecificVars.pathToJquery = '//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/indigo/js/lib/jquery-2.1.1.min';

        <script src="//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/indigo/js/lib/require.min.js"></script>

        <script>
(function(){
  if (window.BOOMR && window.BOOMR.version) { return; }
  var dom,doc,where,iframe = document.createElement("iframe"),win = window;

  function boomerangSaveLoadTime(e) {
    win.BOOMR_onload=(e && e.timeStamp) || new Date().getTime();
  }
  if (win.addEventListener) {
    win.addEventListener("load", boomerangSaveLoadTime, false);
  } else if (win.attachEvent) {
    win.attachEvent("onload", boomerangSaveLoadTime);
  }

  iframe.src = "javascript:void(0)";
  iframe.title = ""; iframe.role = "presentation";
  (iframe.frameElement || iframe).style.cssText = "width:0;height:0;border:0;display:none;";
  where = document.getElementsByTagName("script")[0];
  where.parentNode.insertBefore(iframe, where);

  try {
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  } catch(e) {
    dom = document.domain;
    iframe.src="javascript:var d=document.open();d.domain='"+dom+"';void(0);";
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  }
  doc.open()._l = function() {
    var js = this.createElement("script");
    if (dom) { this.domain = dom; }
    js.id = "boomr-if-as";
    js.src = "//c.go-mpulse.net/boomerang/" +
    "SUWW2-HAKPB-Q4WN7-TQ6VL-GTMT2";
    BOOMR_lstart=new Date().getTime();
    this.body.appendChild(js);
  };
  doc.write('<body onload="document._l();">');
  doc.close();
})();
</script>

            <li class="breadcrumb__item">
                <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/centras/study/postgraduate-taught/ma-modules/TRTPG007">TRTPG007 Advanced Translation into Chinese</a>
                
            </li>
        </ul>
    </nav>

                    <!--endnoindex-->
                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">TRTPG007 Advanced Translation into Chinese</h1>
<p class="p"> The module will consist of practical translation exercises covering a wide range of texts and registers. It aims to develop linguistic and interpretative skills at a highly advanced level as well as to enhance the understanding of the translation process itself.</p>
<p class="p">Credits: 30</p>
<p class="p">Assessment: Students are assessed by coursework (50%) and an unseen 3-hour desk exam (50%). The coursework consists of two 1,500 word assignments.</p>
<p class="p">Tutor: TBA</p>


<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

                    <div class="content-footer">
                                        <hr />
                <div id="content-footer"></div>

                    </div>

                <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/centras/study/postgraduate-taught/ma-modules/TRTPG008">TRTPG008 - Translation and the Web</a>
                
            </li>
        </ul>
    </nav>

                    <!--endnoindex-->
                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">TRTPG008 - Translation and the Web</h1>
<p class="p">The curriculum for this module will be a wide one, encompassing not only translation practices as they are implemented on the WWW but also the social context that surrounds it. Thus topics to be covered will include the history of internet translation; the impact on working practices of on-line machine translation and other translation software and resources; crowdsourced translation; the Wikipedia phenomenon; translation blogs and translation portals; fansubbing; WWW localisation. This will be a largely theoretical module but with a practical dimension. It is anticipated that it will include a certain amount of research content, not least because relatively little has been written on a number of the topics being included.</p>
<p class="p">Credits: 15</p>
<p class="p">Assessment: Two 1,500-word essays, the second of which can have a practical element</p>
<p class="p">Module convenor: Dr Mark Shuttleworth</p>


<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

                    <div class="content-footer">
                                        <hr />
                <div id="content-footer"></div>

                    </div>

                <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/centras/study/postgraduate-taught/ma-modules/TRTPG009-10">TRTPG009/10 - Translation in History: theory, p...</a>
                
            </li>

                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">TRTPG009/10 - Translation in History: theory, practice and reception</h1>
<p class="p"> This module studies the historical development of the theory and practice of translation through an investigation of the role of key individuals and texts significant to literary translation from the Classical tradition to the present. Each session will explore the creative tension between translation and reception studies by examining historical engagements with translation and discussing their relevance to modern thinking around literary translation. <br /></p>
<p class="p">The
module is taught by specialists from a range of departments, including the
Centre for Translation Studies, English, Greek and Latin, Hebrew and Jewish
Studies, School of Slavonic and East European Languages, and School of European
Languages, Culture and Society. Sessions vary annually subject to staff
availability. Example topics include:</p>
<ul class="disc">
<li> Translation in ancient Rome</li>
<li>Translation in the 12th century: an introduction to the first renaissance
in Europe</li>
<li>The first global enterprise: translation and the Jesuit missions,
1550-1750</li>
<li>Latin as a language of translation in Elizabethan England</li>
<li>Quixotic Transformations</li>
<li>Early Hebrew Shakespeare translations</li>
<li>What can translation know?</li>
</ul>
<p class="p">This
module is open to students within the Centre for Multidisciplinary and
Intercultural Inquiry and Greek and Latin. Students from other programmes may
contact the convenor to enquire about availability.</p>
<p class="p">Credits: TRTPG009: 20 credits (intercollegiate modules), TRTPG010: 15 credits<br />Assessment: TRTPG009: 5,000 word essay, TRTPG010: 3,000 word essay<br />Tutor: Various<br />Module convenor: Dr Geraldine Brodie<br /></p>





<h5 class="minor">Preparatory Reading</h5>

<ul class="disc">
<li>Lianeri, Aleka and Vanda Zajko (eds.). 2008. Translation and the Classic (Oxford: Oxford University Press)</li>
<li>Parker, Jan and Timothy Mathews (eds.). 2011. Tradition, Translation, Trauma: the Classic and the Modern (Oxford: Oxford University Press)</li>
<li>Robinson, Douglas (ed.). 1997. Western Translation Theory: from Herodotus to Nietzsche (Manchester: St Jerome)</li>
</ul>


<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">TRTPG041 - Translation Theory</h1>
<p class="p">This module supplements the TRANG001 Language and Translation core module in Term 1. It explores theoretical approaches to translation, investigating key topics in depth, and examines the interdisciplinary contexts of theoretical engagements with translation, with particular reference to the application of philosophical and critical theory and the examination of translation ethics and poetics.  </p>
<p class="p">Term: 2<br />Credits: 15<br />Assessment: 3000-word essay (100%)<br />Module convenor: <a href="mailto:t.hermans@ucl.ac.uk" target="_self">Professor Theo Hermans</a></p>


<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

                    <div class="content-footer">
                                        <hr />

                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">TRTPG042 - Translating Literary Culture</h1>
<p class="p">The MA module in Translating Literary Culture examines the theory and practice of translating text-based literary materials, broadly-defined. The module discusses theoretical engagements with translating literary culture, including notions of voice and style, contextualizing source and target literary systems, and ideological and other issues in the selection and conduct of translations. </p>
<p class="p">The module is taught and assessed in English and welcomes contributions from all languages and cultures. Some practical translation into and out of English is incorporated, allowing students to reflect on the processes of translation and comment on the implications of translating these various text-types from both practical and theoretical perspectives.</p>
<p class="p">Term: 1<br />Credits: 15<br />Assessment: 500-word annotated-translation (10%), 500-word translation commentary (plus supporting translation) (20%) and 1500-word essay (70%)<br />Module convenor: <a href="mailto:g.brodie@ucl.ac.uk" target="_self">Dr Geraldine Brodie</a></p>


<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

                    <div class="content-footer">
                                        <hr />
                <div id="content-footer"></div>

                    </div>

        <article class="block block--col-2">
            <h2 class="as-h5">UCL locations</h2>

                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">TRTPG043- Corpora for translation</h1>
<p class="p"> This module will have clearly defined theoretical and practical elements. The theoretical part will introduce students to the use of corpora for studying language and translation, with the following major focuses: types of language corpus and approaches to analysis; accessing and building corpora; the Web as Corpus; corpus linguistics and machine translation training data. Most of the practical sessions will involve using the Sketch Engine on-line lexical analysis software to carry out corpus analysis. There will also be some work with data visualisation and the opportunity to experiment with a range of digital methods to analyse textual and other kinds of data relevant to translation.</p>
<p class="p">Term: 2<br />Credits: 15<br />Assessment: 1000-word essay (30%) and 2500-word project report (70%)<br />Tutor: <a href="mailto:m.shuttleworth@ucl.ac.uk" target="_self">Dr Mark Shuttleworth</a></p>


<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

                    <div class="content-footer">
                                        <hr />
                <div id="content-footer"></div>

                    </div>

                    </div>

                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">TRTP098 - Dissertation (Translation Research Pathway)</h1>
<p class="p">The MA Dissertation (Translation Research Pathway), the central feature of the MA in Translation (Research Pathway), is 18,000 words long, written in English and submitted at the end of the programme (beginning of September). </p>
<p class="p">The Dissertation (Research) is supervised by a member of CenTraS, CMII or another member of UCL staff in consultation with the Translation MA programme convenor, and addresses a translation studies topic agreed with the supervisor and programme convenor. The dissertation usually focuses on a topic related to the compulsory modules Language and Translation and Translation Theory, and may also refer to other modules studied by the student during the programme, alongside independent research conducted under the guidance of the dissertation supervisor. The dissertation must be a critical essay, and not an annotated translation.</p>
<p class="p">Credits: 90<br />Assessment: 18,000 word dissertation<br /></p>


<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

            var cuttingTheMustard = document.querySelector && window.localStorage && window.addEventListener;

            Modernizr.load({
                //cutting the mustard as used by the BBC
                test : cuttingTheMustard
                //if old browser load the shiv
                ,nope : [
                    '//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/indigo/js/lib/html5shiv-printshiv.min.js'
                    ,'//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/indigo/js/lib/respond.min.js'
                    ,'//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/indigo/js/lib/respond.proxy.min.js'

            });
            //set conditional assets for main.js
            var globalSiteSpecificVars = {
                pathToJquery: '//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/indigo/js/lib/jquery-1.9.1.min'
                ,googleAnalyticsIdsArray: ['google205af8501c1abd6c.html']//specify array of site specific id's NOT UCL generic UA-943297-1

                globalSiteSpecificVars.pathToJquery = '//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/indigo/js/lib/jquery-2.1.1.min';

        <script>
(function(){
  if (window.BOOMR && window.BOOMR.version) { return; }
  var dom,doc,where,iframe = document.createElement("iframe"),win = window;

  function boomerangSaveLoadTime(e) {
    win.BOOMR_onload=(e && e.timeStamp) || new Date().getTime();
  }
  if (win.addEventListener) {
    win.addEventListener("load", boomerangSaveLoadTime, false);
  } else if (win.attachEvent) {
    win.attachEvent("onload", boomerangSaveLoadTime);
  }

  iframe.src = "javascript:void(0)";
  iframe.title = ""; iframe.role = "presentation";
  (iframe.frameElement || iframe).style.cssText = "width:0;height:0;border:0;display:none;";
  where = document.getElementsByTagName("script")[0];
  where.parentNode.insertBefore(iframe, where);

  try {
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  } catch(e) {
    dom = document.domain;
    iframe.src="javascript:var d=document.open();d.domain='"+dom+"';void(0);";
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  }
  doc.open()._l = function() {
    var js = this.createElement("script");
    if (dom) { this.domain = dom; }
    js.id = "boomr-if-as";
    js.src = "//c.go-mpulse.net/boomerang/" +
    "SUWW2-HAKPB-Q4WN7-TQ6VL-GTMT2";
    BOOMR_lstart=new Date().getTime();
    this.body.appendChild(js);
  };
  doc.write('<body onload="document._l();">');
  doc.close();
})();
</script>

                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">TRTP099 - Dissertation</h1>
<p class="p">  The dissertation, of 12,000 words in length, can consist either of an annotated translation (in or out of English; maximum 60% translation, minimum 40% introduction and commentary) or of a critical discussion of theoretical, practical or historical aspects of translation. You are free to choose the topic of your dissertation, subject to approval by the MA programme’s academic coordinator. Preparation for the dissertation involves a research skills course. The dissertation itself is written under one-to-one supervision and submitted at the beginning of September. </p>
<p class="p">Credits: 60</p>
<p class="p">Assessment: One 12,000 word dissertation</p>


<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

                    <div class="content-footer">
                                        <hr />
                <div id="content-footer"></div>

                    </div>

                                  <div class="info">
                                    <h2 class="heading">The resource cannot be found</h2>
                                    <p class="p">
                                      <acronym title="Uniform Resource Locator">URL</acronym>:
                                      https://www.ucl.ac.uk/centras/study/postgraduate-taught/msc-modules/f.m.federici@ucl.ac.uk
                                      <br /><br />
                                    </p>
                                    <h4 class="heading">
                                      Most likely causes:
                                    </h4>
                                      <ul>
                                          <li>There might be a typing error in the address.</li>
                                          <li>If you clicked on a link, it may be out of date.</li>
                                      </ul>
                                    <h4 class="heading">
                                      What you can try:
                                    </h4>
                                      <ul>
                                          <li>Retype the address.</li>
                                          <li>Use the search box above to find what you're looking for.</li>
                                          <li>Go to <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk" title="UCL Website">www.ucl.ac.uk</a> and look for the information you want.</li>
                                          <li><a href="javascript:history.back()" title="Back to previous page">Go back to the previous page.</a></li>
                                      </ul>
                                    <h4 class="heading">
                                      More information:
                                    </h4>
                                    <p class="p">
                                        This error (<acronym title="Hypertext Transfer Protocol">HTTP</acronym> 404 Not Found) means that you have connected to the UCL Website, but the page you wanted was not found. It's possible that the webpage is temporarily unavailable. Alternatively, the UCL Website might have changed or removed the webpage. 
                                    </p>
                                  </div>

        <script>
            var cuttingTheMustard = document.querySelector && window.localStorage && window.addEventListener;

            Modernizr.load({
                //cutting the mustard as used by the BBC
                test : cuttingTheMustard
                //if old browser load the shiv
                ,nope : [
                    '//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/indigo/js/lib/html5shiv-printshiv.min.js'
                    ,'//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/indigo/js/lib/respond.min.js'
                    ,'//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/indigo/js/lib/respond.proxy.min.js'
                ]
            });
            //set conditional assets for main.js
            var globalSiteSpecificVars = {
                pathToJquery: '//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/indigo/js/lib/jquery-1.9.1.min'
                ,googleAnalyticsIdsArray: ['google205af8501c1abd6c.html']//specify array of site specific id's NOT UCL generic UA-943297-1
            }
            if(cuttingTheMustard){
                globalSiteSpecificVars.pathToJquery = '//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/indigo/js/lib/jquery-2.1.1.min';
            }
        </script> 

        <script src="//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/indigo/js/lib/require.min.js"></script>
        <script src='//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/skins/UCLIndigoSkin/default-theme/main.js'></script>
        <script>require(['app/general','theme/indigo-autocomplete-ga','theme/silva','app/searchWithAutoComplete','app/lightbox',]);//load the default stuff</script>

        <script>
(function(){
  if (window.BOOMR && window.BOOMR.version) { return; }
  var dom,doc,where,iframe = document.createElement("iframe"),win = window;

  function boomerangSaveLoadTime(e) {
    win.BOOMR_onload=(e && e.timeStamp) || new Date().getTime();
  }
  if (win.addEventListener) {
    win.addEventListener("load", boomerangSaveLoadTime, false);
  } else if (win.attachEvent) {
    win.attachEvent("onload", boomerangSaveLoadTime);
  }

  iframe.src = "javascript:void(0)";
  iframe.title = ""; iframe.role = "presentation";
  (iframe.frameElement || iframe).style.cssText = "width:0;height:0;border:0;display:none;";
  where = document.getElementsByTagName("script")[0];
  where.parentNode.insertBefore(iframe, where);

  try {
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  } catch(e) {
    dom = document.domain;
    iframe.src="javascript:var d=document.open();d.domain='"+dom+"';void(0);";
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  }
  doc.open()._l = function() {
    var js = this.createElement("script");
    if (dom) { this.domain = dom; }
    js.id = "boomr-if-as";
    js.src = "//c.go-mpulse.net/boomerang/" +
    "SUWW2-HAKPB-Q4WN7-TQ6VL-GTMT2";
    BOOMR_lstart=new Date().getTime();
    this.body.appendChild(js);
  };
  doc.write('<body onload="document._l();">');
  doc.close();
})();
</script>

                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">Inside the Translation Industry</h1>
<p class="p"> <br />Inside the Translation Industry is a two day programme to provide you with useful ideas about how to move into the next step of your professional career. These seminars will help you to get a better understanding of the areas you could get involved in when you finish the MSc course. Sessions are delivered by translation professionals from different backgrounds, institutions and companies, including past students of the MSc, who will talk about their areas of specialisation: audiovisual translation, specialised translation, freelancing, transcreation, accessibility, project management, localisation, CVs, and much more.<br /><br />This is a not-for-credit series of seminars and you are expected to attend all sessions.<br /><br />Convenor: <a href="mailto:m.navarrete@ucl.ac.uk" target="_self">Marga Navarrete</a></p>


<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

                                  <div class="info">
                                    <h2 class="heading">The resource cannot be found</h2>
                                    <p class="p">
                                      <acronym title="Uniform Resource Locator">URL</acronym>:
                                      https://www.ucl.ac.uk/centras/study/postgraduate-taught/msc-modules/m.navarrete@ucl.ac.uk
                                      <br /><br />
                                    </p>
                                    <h4 class="heading">
                                      Most likely causes:
                                    </h4>
                                      <ul>
                                          <li>There might be a typing error in the address.</li>
                                          <li>If you clicked on a link, it may be out of date.</li>
                                      </ul>
                                    <h4 class="heading">
                                      What you can try:
                                    </h4>
                                      <ul>
                                          <li>Retype the address.</li>
                                          <li>Use the search box above to find what you're looking for.</li>
                                          <li>Go to <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk" title="UCL Website">www.ucl.ac.uk</a> and look for the information you want.</li>
                                          <li><a href="javascript:history.back()" title="Back to previous page">Go back to the previous page.</a></li>
                                      </ul>
                                    <h4 class="heading">
                                      More information:
                                    </h4>
                                    <p class="p">
                                        This error (<acronym title="Hypertext Transfer Protocol">HTTP</acronym> 404 Not Found) means that you have connected to the UCL Website, but the page you wanted was not found. It's possible that the webpage is temporarily unavailable. Alternatively, the UCL Website might have changed or removed the webpage. 
                                    </p>
                                  </div>
                                

                                <!-- end main slot where silva content gets rendered--> 
                                <!--End center content area-->
                            </div>

                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">TRANG001 - Language &amp; Translation</h1>
<p class="p">In this module, students engage with aspects of linguistic theory that
are relevant to translation, and also theoretical ideas about translation that
have a direct impact on translation practice. The module provides an introduction to the
sociolinguistic relationship between language and translatorial activities
(including references to interactional interpreting), as perceived within the
discipline of Translation Studies. Early discussions and debates on the
principles of equivalence, loyalty, and faithfulness are presented in relation
to the professional impact and effect of the theoretical thinking, moving onto
professional definitions of adequacy/good enough, and ethics of translation. By incorporating the
study of language with a close look at various more specifically
translation-related topics, this module aims to focus on some of the
theoretical issues that translators need to confront. The module rests on an
understanding of communicative acts as studied in current sociolinguistics. The
module introduces the theoretical study of language mediation and the symbiotic
relationship between language and translation. This is a core module. The
syllabus is research-informed, and whilst being annually reviewed, it is likely
to include references to such topics as translation terminology, grammar
and meaning, translation and culture, translation theory, and descriptive
translation studies.</p>
<p class="p">Term: 1<br />Credits: 15<br />Assessment: 3000-word Essay (100%)<br />Module Convenor: <a href="mailto:m.shuttleworth@ucl.ac.uk" target="_self">Dr Mark Shuttleworth</a><br /> </p>


<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

                    <div class="content-footer">

  var dom,doc,where,iframe = document.createElement("iframe"),win = window;

  function boomerangSaveLoadTime(e) {
    win.BOOMR_onload=(e && e.timeStamp) || new Date().getTime();
  }
  if (win.addEventListener) {
    win.addEventListener("load", boomerangSaveLoadTime, false);
  } else if (win.attachEvent) {
    win.attachEvent("onload", boomerangSaveLoadTime);
  }

  iframe.src = "javascript:void(0)";
  iframe.title = ""; iframe.role = "presentation";
  (iframe.frameElement || iframe).style.cssText = "width:0;height:0;border:0;display:none;";
  where = document.getElementsByTagName("script")[0];
  where.parentNode.insertBefore(iframe, where);

  try {
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  } catch(e) {
    dom = document.domain;
    iframe.src="javascript:var d=document.open();d.domain='"+dom+"';void(0);";
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  }

    var js = this.createElement("script");

  };
  doc.write('<body onload="document._l();">');
  doc.close();
})();
</script>

                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">TRANG002 – Translation Technology</h1>
<p class="p">In this module you apply your theoretical and conceptual background of
translation to a very practical approach of using several translation
technology applications that are used in the translation industry. These tools
include terminology management and translation memory systems. The hands-on
experience with a range of translation tools happens in a dedicated Translation
Lab. Applications include the following: SDL Trados Multiterm
Desktop 2015, SDL Trados Studio 2015, memoQ and a few selected cloud-based systems.</p>
<p class="p">· Credit: 30<br /></p>
<p class="p">· Term: 1, 2 and 3<br /></p>
<p class="p">· Assessment: Translation technology test (40%); Group project (60%).</p>
<p class="p">· Module Convenor: <a href="mailto:c.declercq@ucl.ac.uk" target="_self"><strong>Dr Christophe Declercq<br /></strong></a></p>


<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

        <script src='//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/skins/UCLIndigoSkin/default-theme/main.js'></script>
        <script>require(['app/general','theme/indigo-autocomplete-ga','theme/silva','app/searchWithAutoComplete','app/lightbox',]);//load the default stuff</script>

        <script>
(function(){
  if (window.BOOMR && window.BOOMR.version) { return; }
  var dom,doc,where,iframe = document.createElement("iframe"),win = window;

  function boomerangSaveLoadTime(e) {
    win.BOOMR_onload=(e && e.timeStamp) || new Date().getTime();
  }
  if (win.addEventListener) {
    win.addEventListener("load", boomerangSaveLoadTime, false);
  } else if (win.attachEvent) {
    win.attachEvent("onload", boomerangSaveLoadTime);
  }

  iframe.src = "javascript:void(0)";
  iframe.title = ""; iframe.role = "presentation";
  (iframe.frameElement || iframe).style.cssText = "width:0;height:0;border:0;display:none;";
  where = document.getElementsByTagName("script")[0];
  where.parentNode.insertBefore(iframe, where);

  try {
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  } catch(e) {
    dom = document.domain;
    iframe.src="javascript:var d=document.open();d.domain='"+dom+"';void(0);";
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  }
  doc.open()._l = function() {
    var js = this.createElement("script");
    if (dom) { this.domain = dom; }
    js.id = "boomr-if-as";
    js.src = "//c.go-mpulse.net/boomerang/" +
    "SUWW2-HAKPB-Q4WN7-TQ6VL-GTMT2";
    BOOMR_lstart=new Date().getTime();
    this.body.appendChild(js);
  };
  doc.write('<body onload="document._l();">');
  doc.close();
})();
</script>

                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">TRANG013 - Accessibility to the Media</h1>
<p class="p">This module introduces you to the fascinating professional practice of
making audiovisual material accessible to people with sensory impairments. You
will learn about subtitling for the deaf and the hard-of-hearing (SDH) and
audio description for the blind and the partially sighted (AD). You will cover
areas such as legislation, history and present situation of SDH and AD,
teletext versus SDH for DVD, subtitling and audio describing for children and
adults, live versus pre-recorded SDH and AD, economic and professional aspects,
and the conventions used on screen. You will develop subtitling and audio
description skills in a variety of registers and styles by
translating programmes from various sources (films, corporate videos,
documentaries) and covering a broad range of specialised genres and media
issues. You will produce your own work with appropriate software
and equipment. The module is taught in English and all the activities are carried out
in English.</p>
<p class="p">· Credit: 15<br /></p>
<p class="p">· Term: 1<br /></p>
<p class="p">· Assessment: Subtitling project (50%); Audio description project (50%)</p>
<p class="p">· Module Convenor: <a href="mailto:soledad.zarate.13@ucl.ac.uk" target="_self"><strong>Dr Soledad Zárate</strong></a></p>


<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

                <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/centras/study/postgraduate-taught/msc-modules/trang014">TRANG014 – Language &amp; Automation</a>
                
            </li>
        </ul>

                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">TRANG014 – Language &amp; Automation</h1>
<p class="p">This module is designed to cover a variety of topics concerning the use
of computer systems to present, manipulate, extract or translate information
expressed in natural (i.e. human) language. Areas likely to be covered include
machine translation, post-editing, controlled language and speech recognition. You will
acquire a basic understanding of the technology behind language engineering
applications, and learn to use and evaluate different tools and technologies.
Once again, this module has a strong hands-on focus.</p>
<p class="p">· Credit: 15<br /></p>
<p class="p">· Term: 2<br /></p>
<p class="p">· Assessment: Report (30%); Project (70%)</p>
<p class="p">· Module Convenor: <a href="mailto:r.banos@ucl.ac.uk" target="_self"><strong>Dr Rocío Baños-Piñero</strong></a></p>


<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

                    <div class="content-footer">
                                        <hr />
                <div id="content-footer"></div>

                    </div>

                    </div>

                <!--[if lte IE 7]>&raquo;<![endif]-->
            </li>
            <li class="breadcrumb__item">
                <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/centras/study">Study</a>
                <!--[if lte IE 7]>&raquo;<![endif]-->
            </li>
            <li class="breadcrumb__item">
                <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/centras/study/postgraduate-taught">Postgraduate Taught</a>
                <!--[if lte IE 7]>&raquo;<![endif]-->
            </li>
            <li class="breadcrumb__item">
                <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/centras/study/postgraduate-taught/msc-modules">MSc Modules</a>
                <!--[if lte IE 7]>&raquo;<![endif]-->
            </li>
            <li class="breadcrumb__item">
                <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/centras/study/postgraduate-taught/msc-modules/trang015">TRANG015 – Localisation</a>
                
            </li>
        </ul>
    </nav>

                    <!--endnoindex-->
                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">TRANG015 – Localisation</h1>
<p class="p">This module introduces students to the specific context and
practices of localisation (software, website, videogames). The module provides
students with an awareness of how the localisation industry works, and which
processes are involved in a typical project. Students explore different
localisation features through a number of practical sessions. The objective is
to provide students with the practical skills necessary to develop further
experience in a professional localisation environment. This module
is not language-specific: it is taught in English and all the
activities are carried out in English. </p>
<p class="p"><strong> </strong></p>
<p class="p">· Credit: 15<br /></p>
<p class="p">· Term: 1</p>
<p class="p">· Assessment: Project (100%)</p>
<p class="p">· Module Convenor: <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/centras/study/postgraduate-taught/msc-modules/m.navarrete@ucl.ac.uk" target="_self"><strong>Ms Marga Navarrete</strong></a><br /></p>


<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

            </li>
            <li class="breadcrumb__item">
                <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/centras/study/postgraduate-taught/msc-modules/trang017">TRANG017 – Professional Skills for Translators</a>
                
            </li>
        </ul>
    </nav>

                    <!--endnoindex-->
                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">TRANG017 – Professional Skills for Translators</h1>
<p class="p">This module
will provide you with the professional skills you will need to work in the
world of translation, both as a freelance translator and as an employee of an
institution or translation agency. Through a combination of lectures, seminars,
and project work, you will be exposed to prototypical situations you are likely
to encounter in your future career. The module will cover topics such as
translator ethics, project and client management, customer service, and
business skills. You will work on your own translation projects as part of a
team and receive constructive and relevant feedback on your performance.
Teaching will be interactive and feature real-world examples from many areas of
the industry. </p>
<p class="p"><strong> </strong></p>
<p class="p">· Credit: 15<br /></p>
<p class="p">· Term: 2<br /></p>
<p class="p">· Assessment:
Project management portfolio (100%)</p>
<p class="p">· Module
Convenor: <a href="mailto:l.desilla@ucl.ac.uk" target="_self">Dr Louisa Desilla</a></p>


<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

                    <div class="content-footer">
                                        <hr />
                <div id="content-footer"></div>

                    </div>

                    </div>
                     <div class="content-sidebar">
                                        <div class="site-content__sidebar">

<div class="prebox">
<section class="box box--None">
  
  <i class="fa None"></i> 
  <h2 class="heading">UCL International Student Support</h2>
<ul class="disc">
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/iss" target="_self">Important information for international students</a></li>
</ul>


</section>

</div>


<div class="prebox">
<section class="box box--None">
  
  <i class="fa None"></i> 
  <h2 class="heading">Funding</h2>
<ul class="disc">
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/multidisciplinary-and-intercultural-inquiry/funding-studentships-prizes" target="_self">CMII funding information</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/scholarships/scholarships/graduate/" target="_self">Graduate Scholarships &amp; Awards</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.grad.ucl.ac.uk/funds/" target="_self">UCL Doctoral School Funding</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/ah/figs/wolfson-postgraduate-scholarship" target="_self">Wolfson Scholarships</a></li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/ah/scholarships-and-funding/leverhulme-trust-early-career-fellowships" target="_self">Leverhulme Trust Early Careers Fellowships</a></li>

                <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/centras/study/postgraduate-taught/msc-modules/trang018">TRANG018 - Audio Description for the Blind and ...</a>
                
            </li>
        </ul>
